It does seem that Japan, and especially its government and Tepco, are lurking into a much larger disaster. It is not that storing water ad-infinitum is prone to become impossible and prohibitively expensive, but that such a system is bound to fail... Clearly, contrary to what is being said to the public, a breached and molten core (actually three of them) and storage pools turned into pieces are bound to cave in, experience a major leak, or behave in ways unexpected. Radiation is not contained, and as Russia did, it is necessary to create a sarcophagus (as in Chernobyl) to gain time, and then to create a major piece of public works (of which Japan has seen little) that will need to be many times more expensive than the nuclear plan (i.e. in the billions) to contain groundwater, isolate air, filtrate air, and the like.

This plant is not under control, nor is it ceased to be a danger. What is most worrisome is that Japan, a developed country with the highest degree of knowhow, has been easily overtaken by the complexities of the disaster and there seems to be no solution forthcoming (not just because of cost or complexity, but because of political unwillingness to confront the disaster).

It is quite likely that Japan will have to sacrifice as much as 1% to 5% of its GDP eventually to control this plant; The question is what should the rest of the world do if Japan proves unwilling, unable, and incapable to face the challenge. Radiation respects no borders.

I read in Wikipedia about the situation with Biafra in the late 1960's:

"""
In 1960, Nigeria became independent of the United Kingdom. As with many other new African states, the borders of the country did not reflect earlier ethnic boundaries. Thus the northern desert region of the country contained semi-autonomous feudal Muslim states, while the southern population was predominantly Christian and Animist. Furthermore, Nigeria's oil, its primary source of income, was located in the south of the country.

Following independence, Nigeria was divided primarily along ethnic lines with Hausa and Fulani in the north, Yoruba in the south-west, Ijaws in the south-south and Igbo in the south-east. In January 1966, a group of primarily eastern Igbo led a military coup during which 30 political leaders including Nigeria's Prime Minister, Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa and the Northern premier, Sir Ahmadu Bello were killed.
"""

According to Wikipedia it was from Biafra that Doctors Without Borders came about:

"""
The international humanitarian organisation Médecins Sans Frontières ("Doctors Without Borders") came out of the suffering in Biafra. During the crisis, French medical volunteers, in addition to Biafran health workers and hospitals, were subjected to attacks by the Nigerian army and witnessed civilians being murdered and starved by the blockading forces.
"""

Both of the above quotes are from the Biafra Wikipedia article.

To NYT, I appreciate the article, but this is the follow-up piece I want:
Where does the money come from? Which line item does it appear before it goes covert?
Who manages the money before it gets distributed? Is there an office with a big safe and a slew of cash where a clerk fills out a requisition for $100,000 in unmarked bills? Which office dispenses it, Treasury? CIA?
Who makes the decision to pay? Maybe not the names, but at what level is this decision made and are their different levels of authority? Who is the person who makes the argument to budget this amount? Was this fund affected by the sequester?
Who picks up the cash and makes the delivery? Does that individual sign for it and is he expected to count it upon receipt to ensure accuracy? Is he expected to get a receipt upon delivery? If the receiving party claims there is a shortage who investigates if anyone?
Why deal in cash? Wouldn't wire transfers be more secure and quicker or are the bank fees completely unreasonable?

This all fascinates me.
